document.title: K-12 Louisiana Student Standards for Mathematics

14E3DCF450D44D84A9D659C2F63C200E.description: Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.

9EB1803B6DF7494F823CE76529F06278.description:
Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the
data.

1322D18A0FEF487A9ECDF729B848E6A8.description: Fit a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association.

CD9217CC354F4FE794B07B835FC3B0BC.description: Informally assess the fit of a function by plotting and analyzing residuals.

16268F597BB7400D8AB163F60BAFAD2D.description:
Fit a function to the data; use functions fitted to data to solve problems in the context of the data. Use given
functions or choose a function suggested by the context. Emphasize linear and quadratic models.

F61E3DB52A524D8E8B67DBCC1821A359.description: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.

338C5BDFB22549119E40A47C6520D89B.description:
Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the
context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible
associations and trends in the data.

44EEAC8C674F447F9EA0F150777389AA.description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables.

0FF94922CB6F4A8FA305BBD821549B6B.description:
Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects
of extreme data points (outliers).

45A21D447E36464FAA5E9BC0EC28CE87.description:
Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread
(interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.

99665CA5508E4F6A8ADBA01EFF966EAC.description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable.

63AA9078566B4C499F1F7C7DCDCA3CD6.description: Interpret the parameters in a linear, quadratic, or exponential function in terms of a context.

B9D8FFF5D90D4AB0814C9937C84BBEC7.description: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model.

96B62CA368124C88A5BB8E2C7BBAD516.description:
Observe, using graphs and tables, that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity
increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.

40F6B0468A16440D9719AC68E276BED9.description:
Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a
description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a table).

20BF6AAEA1344B78BBC966A922763BC1.description:
Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a constant percent rate per unit interval relative
to another.

F2A5F185AA174D2D9EF2D45EFB822BBA.description: Recognize situations in which one quantity changes at a constant rate per unit interval relative to another.

156DC64D97CA4B0DBF71609F98EC62F0.description:
Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal intervals, and that exponential functions
grow by equal factors over equal intervals.

4516EC48D1834FBB80F97DD333025873.description: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.

02470E70F5AA4BD4A4C2E2B6D840C156.description: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems.

103D9B2D5A9F4F47830D1E2E0ACB3F65.description:
Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x) + k, kf(x), f(kx), and f(x + k) for specific values of k (both
positive and negative). Without technology, find the value of k given the graphs of linear and quadratic
functions. With technology, experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph that
include cases where f(x) is a linear, quadratic, piecewise linear (to include absolute value), or exponential
function.

31B2382BD6AC41F8A5F932694472376F.description: Build new functions from existing functions.

BEA498EC2B9A40D0BF47C4C37517BADC.description: Determine an explicit expression, a recursive process, or steps for calculation from a context.

652CAB68708B4C8F845BC27C90E818FD.description:
Write a linear, quadratic, or exponential function that describes a relationship between two quantities.
★

4D6C43404F264DECBF798D48FECBDB4A.description: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities.

53345D0F2D1049BE8605FAEA6424CCB6.description:
Compare properties of two functions (linear, quadratic, piecewise linear [to include absolute value] or
exponential) each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal
descriptions). For example, given a graph of one quadratic function and an algebraic expression for another,
determine which has the larger maximum.

C8E65E80F32E4DFC926ABB3B94504EB4.description:
Use the process of factoring and completing the square in a quadratic function to show zeros, extreme values,
and symmetry of the graph, and interpret these in terms of a context.

336D501BE4464F7095254E845426CCC1.description:
Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different
properties of the function.

9F833F373E94465B95D046CD3F660969.description: Graph piecewise linear (to include absolute value) and exponential functions.

418547DE1CEC4168AAAF7A49EBAA65C4.description: Graph linear and quadratic functions and show intercepts, maxima, and minima.

D322C4BB0D3B4582BC9A48842444A612.description:
Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using
technology for more complicated cases. ★

5B88AC0E61B74368B9294F2772294957.description:
Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a linear, quadratic, piecewise linear (to include absolute
value), and exponential function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified interval. Estimate the rate
of change from a graph. ★

223A83A0022F48A3A1949923CB4FF553.description:
Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes.
For example, if the function h(n) gives the number of person-hours it takes to assemble n engines in a factory,
then the positive integers would be an appropriate domain for the function. ★

52B9F1D2EA8E4336BBA44B6FEDC1E0E0.description:
For linear, piecewise linear (to include absolute value), quadratic, and exponential functions that model a
relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and
sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship. Key features include:
intercepts; intervals where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or negative; relative maximums and
minimums; symmetries; and end behavior. ★

B2734BA641964A68939F7C234E45B159.description: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context.

08DD0D890BD7462EB0C8CA2387098F8C.description:
Recognize that sequences are functions whose domain is a subset of the integers. Relate arithmetic sequences to
linear functions and geometric sequences to exponential functions.

CC9AEC8600604038A9BF325E0A32B8F3.description:
Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function
notation in terms of a context.

D88BFD7496DB457FBFED14AC954D4EC7.description:
Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each
element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then
f(x) denotes the output of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).

2274CD4BB49A46A5BEF5C2EC73178FAD.description: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation.

5B94EC4E093B4F46A16EF53813F52E66.description:
Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a
strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection
of the corresponding half-planes.

A6705E37300E4EF8A0499F9A8F20F000.description:
Explain why the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect are
the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x); find the solutions approximately, e.g., using technology to graph the
functions, make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases where f(x) and/or g(x) are
linear, polynomial, rational, piecewise linear (to include absolute value), and exponential functions.
★

584EED9669DF4BE38A2C1427B6669AD5.description:
Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate
plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line).

FA5A1966D0E84DD29E7D4BEC11BD0C29.description: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically.

0C6230FE92AF40EFA9F42CBD62E3B159.description:
Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear
equations in two variables.

E99B5391B42742F1A37F6FEC4B74D5E2.description:
Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation
and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.

307965FAFD5048278DA557B63919B933.description:
Solve quadratic equations by inspection (e.g., for x
2 = 49), taking square roots, completing the square, the
quadratic formula, and factoring, as appropriate to the initial form of the equation. Recognize when the
quadratic formula gives complex solutions and write them as "no real solution.”

F77409D474A349A0834DF1CDA25D23D8.description:
Use the method of completing the square to transform any quadratic equation in x into an equation of the
form (x – p)
2 = q that has the same solutions. Derive the quadratic formula from this form.

89C988BFB2D7482F84BE39BC856FD7DF.description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.

CAC109C2C4364C7196021BC4D927A624.description:
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by
letters.

6EAB41E7F615455994061795769D60B6.description: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable.

E131D29CF7BA4A09AD333AC6D59A255D.description:
Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous
step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to
justify a solution method.

E9DE1D08CE1746F39C2CE0F0E069FC37.description: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning.

F7FC21EDD37D46528D246D78907ADEFD.description:
Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest, using the same reasoning as in solving equations. For
example, rearrange Ohm’s lawV = IR to highlight resistance R.

0C94B77151D54188845FFE950A355CA6.description:
Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by systems of equations and/or inequalities, and
interpret solutions as viable or nonviable options in a modeling context. For example, represent inequalities
describing nutritional and cost constraints on combinations of different foods.

65B5A255561A4CD0A03F16BD0A97CBE5.description:
Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on
coordinate axes with labels and scales.

09720343CCE74B5A90241A17C272B327.description:
Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. Include equations arising from
linear, quadratic, and exponential functions.

F5F04A12C0734006980E9B4A1D92FC62.description: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships.

628E4D0BD2C64072AACB0DD64F9A66E9.description:
Identify zeros of quadratic functions, and use the zeros to sketch a graph of the function defined by the
polynomial.

33B8CC15433C4066BD89B5CB98945AF7.description: Understand the relationship between zeros and factors of polynomials.

51BA4984AB8D42BA88D0997A5807E08C.description:
Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the
operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.

F024E73C378644B4B5EE94D308534CFC.description: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

52FAB8036B5745C68D0110E46631C87D.description:
Complete the square in a quadratic expression to reveal the maximum or minimum value of the function it
defines.

F910B9890CEF4C29B83DC1A75FFC6490.description: Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function it defines.

DEF5A1DACC1E4292B95AC53523A683B7.description:
Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity
represented by the expression. ★

2965526C479049338D87813380014B34.description: Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems.

7277B41BCC4847F3AEF927F1C77D34A2.description:
Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it. For example, see x4 – y
4 as (x
2
)
2 – (y
2
)
2
, thus
recognizing it as a difference of squares that can be factored as (x
2 – y
2
)(x
2 + y2
), or see 2x2 + 8x as (2x)(x) + 2x(4),
thus recognizing it as a polynomial whose terms are products of monomials and the polynomial can be factored
as 2x(x+4).

8A86B14F556D46FB98FDE0C8C53F520F.description:
Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity. For example,
interpret P(1+r)n as the product of P and a factor not depending on P.

0DD8EAC70AE64CE196A356B7449D93E0.description: Interpret parts of an expression, such as terms, factors, and coefficients.

BD44BFA058E742BBAC72258BD0EB59DA.description: Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context. ★
